4 ... h6 is weak.  Your opponent should have continued developing.

You could have tried 5. Nxe5 dxe5 6. Qh5+ Kd7 (If he played Ke7, it would have been mate in four -- see if you can find the mate) 7. Qxf5+ Qc6 8. Qxe5.  For the knight, you get three pawns and your opponent's center is ripped to bits.
A pawn storm this early in the game is very bad play.
Hurrah for king safety!

Your first blunder. A better move was d4!  Bd2 doesn't look that bad, but it turns the pawn storm into a real threat. Notice also that he had constructed a pawn wedge, which will work to his advantage.

Bb5+ is a mistake.  Nd5 would have been much better.  Your opponent should play c6 immediately (which he did) and then play g4 and then bring his knight out from g8.

Ra4 is a bit premature.  Again, h3 or b4 would have been better.  h3 is defensive or in chess-ese prophylactic. b4 could be the start of something strong on black's queenside. For rooks to really succeed, they need space and that is something that's lacking at the moment. The fact that they're connected -- once you get your queen off of the back rank -- means they're mobile and ready to pounce.

Instead of taking with the rook, why not take with the knight?  By taking the rook, you give black chances.  The knight would love to land on d4 and it would push the queen away.

Nd7 is a mistake for black. He should have castled.
Na4 is a mistake.  The correct response for black would have been 17 ... Nac5 18. Nxc5 Nxc5 and you would still have had chances. Better would have been 17. Bxf4 Ne5 18. Rxd6 Nf3+ 19. gxf3.

I see why you chose h5, but Rd1 is SO much better.  Again, you would have had a won position.  Remember, when attacking, try and get all of your pieces involved.  Your rook is doing nothing on f1.
